title: Waugh's Well Walk Route

images.title: John Darch / Waugh's Well
images.caption: Waugh first attracted attention with sketches of Lancashire life and character in the Manchester Examiner. His Lancashire dialect songs, collected as Poems and Songs (1859), brought him local fame. He has been called "the Lancashire Burns." His most famous poem is "Come whoam to thi childer an' me", 1856

images.title: jolmartyn, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View from Waugh's Well over the reservoir and hills.

images.title: Mike Lee / Waugh's Well
images.caption: Waugh's Well on 21 July 2007 after restoration funded by United Utilities. The photograph was taken immediately after the annual reading of Waugh's poems at the well, hence the spray of roses on the well.

images.title: Paul Anderson / Scout Moor High Level Reservoir
images.caption: Scout Moor High Level Reservoir

images.title: John Darch / Cragg High Level Tank
images.caption: Cragg High Level Tank

description: This walk visits Waugh's Well in the Rossendale Valley area of Lancashire. The structure was created to commemorate local poet Edwin Waugh who is known locally as "the Lancashire Burns". It is located at Foe Edge Farm, on the moors above Edenfield, where he spent much time writing. Scout Moor High Level Reservoir is also located next to the well. As such it is a splendid place for a walk with fantastic views over the area from the elevated position. This circular walk uses sections of the Pennine Bridleway and the Rossendale Way to visit the well from Waterfoot. The route then goes on to explore the moorland scenery, visiting Cowpe Reservoir before descending back to Hugh Mill and Waterfoot. To find out more about his Waugh's life and works please click here .
